Award.AbstractNarration:
The meeting `Advances in Asymptotic Probability' will take place in Stanford University, on December 13-17, 2018.
It is expected to gather about 25 talks given by some of the world leaders in probability theory and stochastic processes, and more than
one hundred participants. The workshop will focus on asymptotic properties of large random structures.

Within probability theory and statistical physics one common goal is to understand behavior at macroscopic (and mesoscopic) scales in systems governed by relatively simple local interactions. In recent years there have been numerous significant developments on questions relating to this general theme. Topics represented at the conference will include: integrable probability, interacting particle systems, stochastic partial differential equations; conformal probability, random planar maps; spin glasses, random matrices, Markov chains, random graphs.

A conference webpage can be found at the URL https://sites.google.com/view/amirdembo60/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This workshop gathered many of the world's top probabilists for five days (Dec 13-17 2018)at Stanford University. Twenty-nine presentations were given about a vast array of topicsat the forefront of probability research.
The main focus of the workshop was on the analysis of large random structures and interacting particle systems systems.Within probability theory and statistical physics one common goal is to understand behavior atmacroscopic (and mesoscopic) scales in systems governed by relatively simple local interactions. In recentyears there have been numerous significant developments on questions relating to this general theme.
More specifically, the following areas of research were covered:Random matrix theory; Spin glasses; Markov chains and random walks; Random graphs and networks;Conformally invariant stochastic processes; Hydrodynamic limits; Stochastic partial differential equations.These mathematical models are routinelyused in a variety of applied domains, from physics to statistics and computer science.
A broader impact of this meeting was the expansion of research activities in a range of related fieldsof science (physics, statistics, economics, etc.) and the strengthening of cooperation between groups indifferent areas, with the corresponding benefits to the careers of the the people involved, particularly theyounger researchers.
NSF funding supported the participation of PhD students, postdocs, and other early career mathematicians,who would have otherwise missed this fantastic training opportunity.
